posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Hail, ECBers!!

WoG is down, and I cannot resist the urge to get some form on NWN flowing through my veins, so I started redoing my Cleric Zen Archer build to squeeze in Called Shot, Epic Prowess and Extend Spell. I managed to do so for the first 2 feats, but not willing to drop ANY Wisdom for spellbook management. I think that it's valid enough to mention KillerKat's suggested tweaks as an alternative. So if you want Extend and Empower Spell, drop 2 Great Wisdoms for them.

The title is kind of cheesy, though. Demolition Man is the nickname of former Strikeforce Heavyweight Champion Alistair Overeem, which is nice, and there is also the semantic proximity of Demolition and Implosion, so I thought it was a clever"ish" name, but then I read it now and I thought it to be kinda cheesy. Couldn't think of anything better, so without further delay, ladies (or rather, lady) and gentlemen: The Demolition Man!

I lost the link to the stored database, but I do know that there are very similar builds. But since we started from scratch, I thought this one deserves a topic here.

My offensive spell selection is vital to understand how to use the build, and also why I chose to give up Extend and Empower for more Wisdom:

Lvl 1 - Divine Favor
Lvl 2 - There are no good ones, so I put Invisibility here for scouting / fleeing.
Lvl 3 - Searing Light (put many buffs here, as Searing Light is half-worthless). I use it much to finish off creatures I have used Harm on. You need do only 1d4 damage, and Divine damage resistance isn't common. It prevents you from wasting a better spell to finish off near dead enemies, which is good.
Lvl 4 - Hammer of the Gods (mostly for the stun effect on low-will saving types)
Lvl 5 - Flamestrike
Lvl 6 - Harm / Blade Barrier
Lvl 7 - Word of Faith
Lvl 8 - Fire Storm
Lvl 9 - IMPLOSION (It deserves capital letters )

As you can see, there are good offensive spells or buffs to use in abundance at each spell level. You will have a high enough WIS score to choose any number that is sufficient to last you through the day. The high caster level means you don't NEED Extend, and the availability of good offensive spells at all levels means you don't NEED empower. If I could squeeze them in without hurting my sniping or lowering my Wisdom, those two feats would be my next choice, alas you need to decide between being the best at what you do or being able to do more things. I chose the former. But as KillerKat suggested, you could go with them as well without hurting the idea. Another of his suggestions which kinda made me think for a while was dropping Martial weapons and settling for a sling. But I don't think I have EVER seen a WoG mob drop a sling or bullets consistently, so I chose to keep the bow, as there are places where you can stock up on fire arrows for free. Still, if you do decide to go with this, take Silent Spell, and you can prevent casters from casting if you cast silence on yourself and approach them. I, however, find that you are already a caster's worst nightmare, alongside high SR monks, so you needn't dwell on that much.

You know that NASTY mage boss that has killed many of your toons with IGMS, Bigby's 9 and then some other crap? Approach him / her invisible and fire one single Implosion. Revenge will be yours! Or stay from afar, sniping the shit out of them, not allowing them to cast.

Another thing I need to address here is the domain selection. I chose Plant because in regular NWN, the only item slot that buffs natural AC is the amulet, which happens to be the same that buffs Wisdom. But if your server, like WoG, has plenty of non-amulet custom items that enhance Natural AC or alternatively Wisdom belts, or cloaks, or helms, then Plant is droppable. Trickery is the main one, because I use invisibility to scout a lot, and because of the 50% concealment, which is great against archers. You needn't worry about meleers, as most of the time they will not manage to get close to you. In WoG, pick any god that has trickery and allows you to be lawful. I don't know them by hard yet, so I don't know which ones.

In the early levels, I usually summon a lot with 8 STR Clerics. I have 3 of those: this guy, my Cleric Wizard Monk and my Shadow Priest build, which I will post here soon enough. Let the summons be your meatshield and rain arrows from afar, or use all your slots in lvl 2 for invisibility and all others as Summon Creature and just watch them do the dirty work for ya. That will work in WoG.

You can take Rogue at 40 is to avoid XP penalty, but then you'll lose a couple of minor things: 1 to saves vs spells (Spellcraft 45) and 1 Concentration, besides 2 levels of full Tumble AC and UMD. Either way is fine, really.

This is a quite cheap build, I realize, so if you don't want to risk being drunk with power, my advice is not to try it .

Whaddya think? Hip, see how much it changed since that early draft I sent you?

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Why did you wait until level 38 to take those 11 points of Heal? You are saving more than 11 points every level before that one. You could have gotten 11 points of Heal much much earlier, at the very beginning, where they would be more helpful.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:Why did you wait until level 38 to take those 11 points of Heal? You are saving more than 11 points every level before that one. You could have gotten 11 points of Heal much much earlier, at the very beginning, where they would be more helpful.
Very true, actually, the points spent in Heal were leftovers. I wanted Listen, UMD, Spellcraft, Concentration and Tumble. As I was building, I kept accumulating the points up until level 38 because I didn't know how many I'd have left and I was too lazy to do the math. I stand corrected, then, they can be taken from levels 1 to 8, or, if you feel the need, they can be spent in other skills as well, as Heal is not a key skill to have. But regardless, thanks for pointing it out!

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
In the example for level 1:
01: Concentration(4), Spellcraft(4), Save(12),
This means that at level 1, you put 4 points into Concentration, and put 4 points into Spellcraft, and you save 12 points to be used later (don't put them into any skill at this time).

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
If you want a more caster version of this build, you can get rid of the bow feats for metamagic feats. That way you can be a more effective caster while not losing many AB points. I have a few comments, however. Maximize Spell is very good for arcane casters, but for Clerics it is less useful because on levels that you can maximize a certain good spell, there is generally a better spell to be memorized. I also slightly tweaked the skills because on WoG there has been a change where True Seeing now adds to Spot, so Listen was dropped in favor of Spot. I also reduced UMD by 10, but if you play on high magic, just take 10 points off of Heal and put them there.

One last thing: if you feel the need to cast offensive spells one level higher, then you could swap Extend for Silent Spell (and use the combo of casting silence on yourself and getting near casters to prevent them from casting). But in my experience, the loss of Extend Spell causes Clerics more trouble than it's worth, because of the limited Divine Favor duration.

posts.author: exalos
posts.content:
First time posting on any thread so Hello everyone :D

Anyway I have a newbie question.I don't understand the use of UMD,I have tried leveling with or without it and I see no difference, can anybody explain me what it does ??

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
http://nwn.wikia.com/wiki/Use_magic_device
It allows you to use things that you "shouldn't" be allowed to use because of class, race, or alignment. This includes scrolls, so non-casters with a high-enough UMD can cast after all.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
exalos wrote:
First time posting on any thread so Hello everyone :D

Anyway I have a newbie question.I don't understand the use of UMD,I have tried leveling with or without it and I see no difference, can anybody explain me what it does ??
Well, we didn't know you existed until you at least said "Hello!" so now that you have... WELCOME ABOARD!  We hope you'll learn enough on your visits to begin building your own toons from scratch.  The guild will be there to assist you whenever you need help or opinions.

Empyre's comment is general enough for you to grasp the basic function of UMD, but I think it may be time for someone to write a mini-guide about UMD's nuances.  Some aspects are not that easy to understand IMO.  edit:  Here's a more detailed guide I threw together that addresses design considerations for the UMD skill.

One thing UMD does NOT do is ignore a proficiency.  So that sweet katana that can only be used by Weapon Masters will not be available for a UMD user unless they have Exotic Weapon Proficiency.

posts.author: jakinbandw
posts.content:
So I'm confused by one thing in  this build:

Why start with 14 dexterity? Surely it would make the early game easier to have 14 str and use a melee weapon till you unlock zen archery right? Once you have Zen archery, Wis is used to aim, and str is used to deal damage so having a 14 dex doesn't seem that useful.

Am I missing something?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: At the risk of disturbing a slumbering beast, I think it's fair to say that Max builds for level 40 power, not for easier early gameplay. Have a look at his guides to building and playing in the Game Guides section and you'll get a better flavour of where he' coming from. Many times you will have to work hard at lower levels in order to achieve greatness later. At least here he does make the concession of using summons heavily at those early levels, meaning you can hide behind a rock and accumulate xp by default. This is not a build for going toe-to-toe - it's for blowing enemies to pieces.

posts.author: jakinbandw
posts.content:
Even then though, what does 14 dex do late game? 

Oh, I see, it's +3 ac over going with 8 dex. I get it now. Because late game using monk bonus armor. At the loss of 3 damage per bow attack and +3 to touch attacks with clerics kinda do need a bit of. 

Is the 3 exta AC worth it?

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
I'm going into alien territory for me now, being a non-caster and non-PW player, but there are plenty who will put me back in my box if I misspeak...

This is in no way intended to be a touch attack build, and the archery is more of a fallback position. This about an OP Cleric who doesn't really need to engage with weaponry very much at all. However, Max plays on WoG, and I'm reliably informed that AC is crucial there. The question I have is why Epic Prowess rather than Armor Skin? But maybe that's just me.

(Gods, I hope I've got at least some of this right...)

Cheers

posts.author: EasternPromises
posts.content: You get 3 AC from Dex, and Divine Power sets your Str to 18 no matter where it started (unless you already had higher). Since if you're concerned about bow damage you're probably using DP, Dex is the better pick.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
I played this guy to 40 on WoG, and you won't miss the strength. Extended DP lasts 76 rounds a pop (I swapped martial for extend). Dex gives you higher armour and saves, str gives you nothing. One of the best things about building with cleric.

You get Zen archery at level 6. Until then, you're better off summoning and shooting anyway, unless xp is extremely tight.

posts.author: Thorsson

posts.author: jakinbandw
posts.content:
Divine favor, which does unresistible damage lasts only 1 turn, no matter how many caster levels you have. I personally don't like the 1 turn duration because there are often situations where you buff, then need to walk, or talk or something else before the fight. 2 turns gives time for things like that. 

I value that+spellbook management over a single +1 to hit. Even if that might be a bit foolish of me.

If you did want to make the change (or changes to other builds in future) can I recommend you try using Kamiryn's CBC Excel Spreadsheet to see what builds look like with adjustments which you suggest?
It can be found in the NWN Vault: https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... ulator-cbc
It will output the final ending stats etc so is a very valuable tool! I use it a lot with building and I find it a huge time saver.
Before I used it I was using the Pretty Good Character Builder Module to design builds. God that took a long time...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
sataricon wrote:I'm level 10 now and love this build.
But i've been wondring can i take the rogue level early to gain umd an some quailty of life skills?
Will this gimp this build too much?
Clerics are a very strong class in mid-magic environments such as WoG
If you take the rogue level now you will want a later rogue level to max out rogue skills / get tumble.
You will also lose 1 AB permanently, which is valuable for all support and warrior classes, albeit Cleric has many ways to work around it, there still is the +20 AB cap to consider (ie you cannot raise your AB higher than 20 more than your Base AB + attribute modifier)
Might mean you take a Cleric 35 / Monk 2 / Rogue 3 split. 
If you want maximal late game power suggest sticking with the original build, Max was excellent for optimising for ultra late game
I personally think you should be able to manage without UMD, particularly if you took the Animal Domain on WoG, summon spells + animal domain should get you to epic pretty easily (albeit with resting to refresh spells)

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
My experience with WoG is that I can cap the primary stat with items alone in early to mid epic levels, but as ratty_uk discussed, there could be tradeoffs, big ones being important immunities such as death immunity, freedom, leveldrain / ability score, knockdown immunity etc...

I do find it hard to cap the primary stat pre epic unless I use spells and potions (for example, casting bulls strength then greater bulls strength plus items is a pretty simple way to cap strength pre epic but there are costs with them items without a sequencer)

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
The trade offs are less impacting on this build, any cleric build really, as they are the least item dependant to mitigate most things with spells. They also have some additional versatility opportunities with domain choice.

A cleric, for example, can net 2x +2 Wisdom rings, +3 Wisdom helm, +2 Wisdom cloak, +2 Wisdom neck as soon as they can afford the coin for a +11 wisdom total (there also shields, belts with wisdom on it that are less useful but can cap you). They can then mitigate negative energy effects, death effects, paralysis/entanglement effects, level drain effects all via spells. I tend to wear the immune fear belt all the time and shift in DR belts where useful simply because fear effects are so debilitating so that slot is not available for me on anything other than a Paladin build.

Dexterity, Charisma and Constitution are similarly easy to cap as soon as you have the coin. I am not sure about Intelligence and Strength (pre-Epic)as I have not went looking for / cataloging purchase locations for those yet.

As noted, when not on clerics, there are other things worth considering for those slots, but spellbook casters have less flexibility with spell slot loss resulting in memorised spell lose from equipment shifting than melee.

My current “Demolition Man” build is level 25 (early epic) and has Wisdom overcapped at +13, Strength capped with bulls strength, Dex capped with Cat’s Grace and Con at half of cap. She wears immune knockdown/dodge boots and an immune fear belt. This is with non-purchasable gear but without farming as I really lack the knowledge on this server to farm much currently. Also, it is important to note that your buying opportunities open up dramatically at level 20 as there is a level gated store.

Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
can net 2x +2 Wisdom rings, +3 Wisdom helm, +2 Wisdom cloak, +2 Wisdom neck as soon as they can afford the coin for a +11 wisdom total (there also shields, belts with wisdom on it that are less useful but can cap you).
This is what is in error.

Not meaning that one cannot get these - one can.

But it is easier and more effective to get the +4 Wis versions, so that you can reserve the other slots for other things.

Call it optimizing, if you will.

I was perhaps too harsh with my opinion.  It is just that I seek to optimize as soon as I can, in order to get the most out of WoG.

As for "abuse the most" - why would one say that this is abuse?  I really have to say that if it is legitimately possible, then it is not abuse!

Especially when it is just purchases from a Merchant.

That cannot be considered abuse!

Abuse is like when one coaxes the AI to get "stuck" somewhere on the environment, making an otherwise impossible (or very difficult) foe a sure kill for easy XP and/or items.

Or Invis/Gr. Sanc/Hide to grab some treasure.

Etc.

Why is it considered abuse when I come out of the Moathouse with over 30,000 gp?  A bit of investment in some Int and that gets even higher.  Sell that stuff at the right Merchant, and one has turned the 30,000 into over 50,000!  That is not abuse, that is being smart!

Then knowing what Merchant sells what where, and to whom, at which level, etc.

And if I am killing the guardians of treasure troves, then that is not abuse either!

Now, we could talk about Meta-Knowledge.  That is a creature of another skin.  WoG play really relies on a LOT of meta-knowledge.  This is because much has been altered from "standard" vanilla NWN, from spells, to feats, to crafting, to the creature AI, etc.

It takes experience to be able to deal with these type of changes.  And of course, knowledge of the Server.  WoG is not exactly very newbie friendly!  Where does one go from x, to complete y?  Well, good luck with that, there are very little in the way of directions, explanations, or much of anything other than "do this for me and I will award you".

I point to the Sickle quest as a prime example of this.  One can get it really early, and wonder how in the hell one can complete it for practically forever, for there is absolutely no information about it.

Not to mention the Ranger's quest!  If one is not a certain Class, one may dither around forever, never completing it, because it is extremely hard to actually complete if a non-Rogue.

Dirty bird.  One might pick the quest up (and even that is not a certainty!) but I will bet dimes to dollars that completing it will require either meta-knowledge or an extremely large amount of luck!

Fact is, much of the beginning areas ala Hommlet and surrounds depends on meta-knowledge of the PnP modules!

I'd like to see a newbie find the Golden Skull the first time in the Temple without Meta-Knowledge!  There is absolutely no explanation or clue to the whereabouts of it.  And completing the ToEE quest depends on it.

Or find White Plume Mountain!  Good luck with that!

Find the Hill Giant Steading.  That thing is cleverly hidden!

I know all this is true, due to the amount of "tells" I get ingame from newbies stuck, trying to find their way forwards.  And from the difficulties I have had (and still have, for example, in UM) of trying to navigate WoG.

So, to re-iterate, it is very easy to get gold on WoG, hit the +12 stat max on most stats (those that are not have already been posted), and that meta-knowledge is practically a must in order to be able to complete many quests on WoG.

posts.author: webshaman1
posts.content:
+4 and higher gear abounds, especially if one knows where to find it.

This is probably the "meta-gaming" thingie some have brought up.

And then someone brought up "it can't be done without Critwall!" yadda yadda yadda.

Well, yes, it can.  In fact, it can be done right outside of Hommlet.

Not the +4 stuff, but power levelling and gold and items.

I have seen newbies finding this out a few hours into their first game on WoG who start in Hommlet, for obvious reasons.

Most start farming the Bandits early, I have seen individuals creating piles of their gear and lugging them back to poor Jaroo & Co (before they find an even better merchant, that is!).

So newbies were leaving Hommlet with a sizeable sum to begin with, even without a sizeable knowledge (re: meta-knowledge of the Server).

This is what I call "normal progression" - action, reaction sort of thingl

"Hey, these [insert opponent x] have items on them that can be sold for good gold!" 

It doesn't take a genius to connect the dots further.

Depending on what type of exploration the newbie does from Hommlet further, this can easily be expanded on,

So then let us go forward in time a week - newbie has a new "build" - maybe one from these hallowed halls.  Knows more about the Server, can better plan the progression of the new build BUILT ON PREVIOUS KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE i.e. meta-knowledge!

So let us take hypothetical newbie, and extrapolate further - say they meet a WoG veteran ingame, kick off some great adventure, yadda yadda yadda.  Their knowledge and experience regarding WoG takes a quantum sprung.  Depending on the player they have met, it could be small, or gigantic.

posts.author: Orion

Greetings and hello Revik!

Congratulations on taking the plunge into WoG!

WoG has a deity system that restricts clerics domains. 

I used the deity search function (http://world-of-greyhawk.github.io/deity/search.html) which I presume you also used and I cannot find plant and trickery.

If I could suggest domains for our demolition man you intend to play:

Plant and Animal (Ehlonna, Obad-Hai, Beory). Plant provides barkskin and creeping doom, Animal provides empowered summons and Cat's Grace.

Trickery and Travel (elf / halfling only, Sehanne Moonbow and the new halfling Deity Brandobaris I think its called. )

Trickery and Law (Tiamat) -> Law for Lesser Mind Blank, very handy in parties

Hope this helps

Humans get one free multiclass, not two. Cleric -> Monk is one (Free) adding anything other than a prestige class at this point is an xp penalty. You could add Assassin for all of the Rogue goodness without the XP penalty if you are fine with being evil.

I don't quite understand the value of zen archery here? Conserving spell slots?
Zen Archery allows you to use your WIS modifier instead of DEX modifier when attacking with a ranged weapon. Since this build has 14 DEX and 38 WIS, I think the reason for taking it is VERY CLEAR. Instead of +2 to AB from DEX, you get +14 from WIS. You gain +12 ranged AB with 1 feat. As a comparison, Weapon Focus: Longbow gives you +1.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Ok guys, apparently I have missed a LOT of comments in my hiatus. I don't know if the people who made them are still playing this build but it doesn't hurt to try.

Firstly, since this build is mine, I would like to comment a few things and try to clear up some of the misunderstandings regarding how it works or should work or even is intended to work as per the original builder's perspective.

This build should NEVER EVER be played as a Full Plate Sword & Shield type of character. If you want to play one of those, I could probably refer you to a few dozen other builds who would excell at that. This is an ARCHER / CASTER, so you can reliably stick summoned units or teammates in front of you and just fire a host of arrows or a few well-chosen spells from afar. This playstyle will work all the way from level 1 to high epics, where you might need to add a few tricks to your bag, because by then, summoned units will die too fast to be worth your trouble. The fact that someone is ABLE to play it this way is only a testament to the power of the Cleric class, not necessarily a feature of the build.

Now, please understand that, except for my Magical Master build, no build can do it all (Ok, the MM can't set traps, but that's about it! LOL.). All builds WILL have STRENGTHS and WEAKNESSES and the builders KNOW what they are. Now, if you're going to play a build that was made by someone else, you will eventually figure them out as well, provided you're giving yourself the chance to do so. To try to smoothen out (if that word even exists) your learning curve, allow me to state the following:

THERE ARE THREE BASIC WAYS TO MITIGATE THE BUILD'S WEAKNESSES (in CAPS merely for emphasis):

1- Through equipment or items: That fighter guy you have with abysmal Will saves can equip a belt of Fear immunity, or take a Clarity potion to fight Dragons or Undead. That Mage you have with a laughable Fortitude save can wear a belt of Death Immunity or use a scroll of Spell Mantle to avoid those insta-death spells. You can use Wands to buff up with characters who wouldn't otherwise be able to. Just from a simple drinking Barkskin, Bless, Aid, Cat's Grace potions and using a Brooch of Shielding and a Dust of Disappearance, you can gain 2 AB, 8-9 AC and 50% concealment. That is HUGE in the early levels, and WILL make a difference in whether you succeed or die in a challenging battle. Imagine if you have a potion of Haste!

Knowing what the build's weaknesses are, you can mitigate or in some cases circumvent them enirely with the appropriate items. 

2- Through PLAYSTYLE adjustments: Similarly to the statement above, there are TOOLS that you need to have in your toolbox, there is knowledge you need to have about the game, to be able to play certain builds. These only come with Experience in the game. For example: Playing a DEX-based Assassin is VERY DIFFERENT from playing a STR-based Barbarian. Playing an Arcane caster is basically the opposite of playing an arcane Spellsword. You SHOULD be able to adjust your playstyle to the character. 

To exemplify how knowledge of the game can improve your playstyle, I'll share something of an "insider" secret that I use A LOT. Knowing how attacks are added to each 2-second flurry in a round can help you use Knockdown or Disarm more effectively. If your character has 3 attacks per round, they will attack as follows: 1-1-1. Obviously in this case, the first attack is the one at the highest BAB. However, if you drink a Haste potion with said character, it will now have 4 attacks per round, so it will now do a 2-1-1 attack flurry. In this case, however, the first attack continues to be the one at the highest level, but the added Haste attack ALSO COMES AT FULL BAB. Extra attacks are added last, so suppose your AB is 20, you'll have a 20-15-10 attack schedule. When you drink the Haste potion, your attack schedule will now be: 20/15-10-20. so the first two attacks and the last attack are the highest. So, you should try to KD an enemy on the first and last attack if you're hasted, or just in the 1st if you're not.

Playstyle adjustments also require a knowledge of how the build works, when it's in the developing stages and when it's finally blossomed and can wreak havoc with its tools. For example. I have a build here called the Draconic Arcanist. That build ROCKS in high levels, but it's EXTREMELY DIFFICULT to play all the way to level 30 basically. I bet you if you pick it up and take it for a spin, you WILL DIE SO MUCH you'll never get to see it blossom. And trust me, I have leveled it from 1-23 on WoG. It F***ING HURTS. But, here's the catch. I KNOW the build sucks until it matures, so I know I'll have to rely on items more than I normally do with other builds before it can finally be self-sufficient. So, how did I play it? I BLEW ALL MY GOLD IN CONSUMABLES all the way to 20th level. It does require a lot of consumables given how easy gold comes on WoG for you to be poor at level 20, but I can say I did it. It was hard, I died many times, but I did it. Yes, it does require knowledge of the server, so if you're playing somewhere for the first time, stay away from it! This is the difference between "learning" a build and adjusting it. That build is SUPPOSED TO SUCK in those early levels. So, it becomes a matter of how crafty you can be to get around it. You can, of course, change the build and make it worse because you aren't crafty enough or knowledgeable about the server enough to play it, but all in all it will be a frustrating experience.

Here's a few examples of things you can incorporate into your playstyle to make it more versatile and make yourself a better NwN player:

2.1- Using Darkness to HiPS (you cast Darkness on yourself, hide, then step out into the open, kill something, step back in, hide, rinse and repeat). Those tactics can be VERY USEFUL in some encounters where you have a caster that you need to neutralize surrounded by scary minions. They won't see you in Darkness, so you can hide and then reposition and take them 1 by 1)

2.2- The Taunt / Expertise combo: This combo is SO USEFUL, and AFAIK I'm the only one who uses it. You guys really have no idea how good it can be. You activate Expertise and attack. then while in attack mode, you Taunt and click on the sword icon on the top left of your screen to cancel the attack action (the Taunt action icon should be right beside it). Your character starts Taunting in Expertise mode (+5 AC), and Expertise only deactivates when you FINISH the Taunt action and the result comes, then you can re-click on Expertise and attack again. Now you have +1 AB and +5 AC for the next 6 rounds in case of a full Taunt. But after you Taunt, you don't really need to re-activate Expertise if you're not being hit. You can instead turn on Power Attack to do more damage, or just do a regular attack with +6 AB if you're having trouble hitting. That combo alone will help you immensely when playing Paladins, Bards or Blackguards in those early levels.

3- Making adjustments to the build itself:

I chose to put this item 3rd because it should be 3rd in every situation, except when you SEE a clear improvement that can be made to a build that the original builder hadn't considered. I doubt that's the case with this one, though. You may change it for personal flavor, and do what Orion suggested, going Cleric 35 / Monk 2/ / Rogue 3. That's certainly a viable tweak, which I considered, but ultimately decided against. I HAVE played this build from 1-36 on WoG, so I know it works and does EXTREMELY WELL in almost all areas. I believe my friend BlackCobra and his mate Mr.Zork ran a party all the way to 40 on WoG with this build teamed up with GDL's Charnel Lord. They just WRECKED the entire server. 

Anyway, my point here is that if you're having trouble with a build, perhaps changing the build isn't the solution most of the time. You should also consider equipping it differently (and even having different items for different situations) and adjusting your playstyle before you consider making a change to the build itself. I can say that more often than not, the problem is not on the build itself.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi Max!

Thanks for replying! I have learnt a lot about casters since there was the discussion, cleric casting there are still things I am learning. I have read all your guides, and I have learned your Taunt/Expertise combo and have been using this in other builds (see this one for example), I have been encouraging other players to use it and have referred other players to your post. 

I will admit to not enjoying solo leveling this build with the early summon reliance. The thing was, I could see the absolute power in this build. I in fact searched for a whole bunch of build adjustments which includes creating a melee version (which I started playing, and it played fine - its a cleric after all). 
But that is simply my playstyle, I enjoy being in their face tanking things whilst dealing a pile of damage, I am the one tanking for the summons who generally always have absolutely abysmal AC, it just makes my character feel like he or she is "the boss". Avado's guide describes this playstyle well, when he describes clerics as "tanks", in many ways his guide resonates much more strongly with me about how I want to play compared with other guides.
So in terms of the build perhaps it is just a playstyle adjustment and I can potentially learn to enjoy a different playstyle with this build. You have kindly made some great suggestions on playstyle adjustments and I will try them again another day. But even still solo archer builds I hesitate to play now. 
Parties are obviously different and having all those spells at ones disposal with DC casting is incredible, I would definitely play this one in a party having played a zen cleric archer of my own in a party with Aquarius and Franz into the Demonweb pits and Lolth, we were also destroying the server with Dwarven Defender and Divine Damage Bard until Franz became inactive.

I have spoken with BlackCobra about this build (who has taught me a lot over the last 8 months), who told me about his adventures with MrZork, defeating every major challenge with ease and reassured me it was one of the most powerful builds he has ever played.
One thing BlackCobra did comment that I remember in particular was the amazing amount of AC the build had. I assume he is referring to a massive power boost when that Monk 1 level is obtained at level 22 for wisdom AC. I never took this build that far.
Now that I have connected the dots, I can see that this is when summons start to "fall off" so to speak and this is a perfect time for the build to start tanking mobs potentially, if this is required? I can imagine with all that wisdom AC, even if an enemy walks up and starts to melee the cleric, one can simply continue firing?

Great to see you active again Max and thanks for responding! There are some very valuable insights you have given, much appreciated.

Now that I have connected the dots, I can see that this is when summons start to "fall off" so to speak and this is a perfect time for the build to start tanking mobs potentially, if this is required? I can imagine with all that wisdom AC, even if an enemy walks up and starts to melee the cleric, one can simply continue firing?

Great to see you active again Max and thanks for responding! There are some very valuable insights you have given, much appreciated.
Orion, one thing I forgot to comment on and would be too extensive to type on my Ipad, is when you say that this is "your preferred playstyle" as though it's a boundary you're not willing to cross. I know where you're coming from. I myself have been there and done that, but I've also moved on from that and invite you to do the same. Don't restrict yourself from being all you can be when the sky is the limit. Why would you play 100 different toons the same way? Wouldn't that be extremely boring? From my perspective, you may have an initial favorite playstyle, and that's absolutely OK, but you'll never regret adding new stuff to your bag of tricks. Believe me when I say that it's A LOT OF FUN to learn to play a build that does the opposite of your favorite playstyle as long as you dive in head first into the experience. 

Let me share with you the story of how I played Nathyrra (my remake of her anyway) from 1-40 on WoG. She was an eye-opener. For the first time in my life, I was playing a dedicated stealther with Sneak Attack and trap-setting skills. It was somewhat difficult at the start, but BOY it was PRICELESS when she set a bunch of Epic traps and MELTED Lord Robilar instantly before he could even touch her. She walked around in Stealth, attacked out of the blue, cast Darkness, went in, hid, came back out, attacked and sometimes paralyzed another foe, went back in, hid again. I would never imagine I'd have so much fun playing her. She's far from an optimized build, at least to my standards, but she did SO MUCH BETTER than I was expecting and I learned SO MUCH from that experience, as I never imagined I would. And I had A BLAST doing it, because I was really open-minded about it.

It's easy to see why you'd incorporate the Taunt/Expertise combo into your strategy, as it does suit a guy who sits in the front and tanks the enemies, but for me at least, part of the fun and the reason I love this game so much even after SO LONG is that there's always something new to learn! I have a favorite playstyle, but I also have many other playstyles that I can go to when a build is suposed to be played a certain way. If you look at my Draconic Arcanist, and try to imagine HOW HARD it is to level that guy up solo from 1-23 on WoG, being that he only has access to 5th level spells by level 20, and takes a LONG TIME to have more than 2 attacks per round, even though he's an arcane spellsword. Then you really have to start thinking outside the box. What I mean is, you have a problem. How do you solve it? With these tools at your disposal, what can you do? To me, that's fascinating.

And last but not least, I'd like to share an experience I had with THIS build, Demolition Man (who I ironically play as a female character LOL), on WoG, where I beat the Nulb pirates at level 7 solo with it. The possibilities are truly endless as long as your mind is open enough. I sent a Skelly warrior from Animate Dead buffed with Bull's Strength and Darkfire in, while I was invisible, waited for it to get surrounded, and then cast Hammer of the Gods. Dazed EVERYONE cuz her Wisdom is insanely high, and then the Skelly and my arrows finished the job. They all died without touching my character. It felt AMAZING.

Anyway, my point is, as we play the game again, and start new toons, we have the opportunity to learn new tricks, and that's a good thing! It's a GREAT thing, and it's what makes this game so special that I keep coming back to it even after all these years. The only reason I don't play more is that my computer is really shitty and doesn't run EE. And sadly, Wise has stopped working on the Old World, and hardly anybody logs on there anymore. If you're interested, we could team up and play a party from 1-40 on WoG 1.69. Let me know via PM.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hi Max!

I'd love to party with you one day, there are so many tricks and tips I learn from other players that I have adopted, things like crafting / setting traps, darkness/ultravision, damage shields then the stuff that I read like Expertise/Taunt which I have adopted. (I think you will be interested to know btw, I am currently practicing the Expertise -> Attack -> wait until enemy attacks -> Taunt (by clicking top left) -> Expertise -> Attack combo, so I can use expertise essentially unbroken while taunting and subsequent attacking, using the Taunt during a quiet period where there is no enemy flurry or the flurry is low AB attacks only -  I can pull it off maybe 60-70% of the time at the moment).

RE 1.69 there is still a group that runs on the Old Server on Wednesday Nights US time (East? Or West? Sorry I am not from the US so I am not 100% sure), Grom, BC, Zel, Ddad, MrZork and others run it, Sadly I only have the EE version or I would have gone with them. Otherwise the 1.69 server is somewhat quiet, which is a good thing for some, sometimes a crowded server means one has to wait for certain quests and adventures.

If you are on the EE server we can team up too, we can get a group together, I party with a few players regularly too so we can all join in and conquer all challengers.
I've been on a large number of Monday night runs (US time again) since November last year, given that is weekly, it is a lot of runs. 
There is a nice collection of screenshots which can be accessed from here onwards :)

RE archer playstyle its not that way at all, there isn't any hard boundary. I just find it more fun if I can tank things like a boss at the moment if I need to, I've done the archer stuff, but never felt the desire to really level one up especially since a Monday Night Crew party of four of us took four archers (including Gnolem, a gnome wizard arbalest played by MrZork he was the most tanky of all of us) at level 10-15 or so to fight the Black Dragons in Undermountain. The plan was for the summons to tank, but alas they got shredded, we got dispelled, we got feared by the auras, and there was a total party kill, since then I want to make sure every party has a dedicated tank (not just summons, even the elemental princes/princesses), and that includes solo play :( 

That being said, all that Wisdom AC says to me your build is a tank, so BC and yourself have changed my mind, I'll play solo Demolition Man up to 40 one day, I'm sure I will learn a lot and enjoy it all.

Was wondring if i can skip 1 epic wisdom to get extended for devine power?


Sent from my SM-A505F using Tapatalk
Hey man! 

You could drop a feat for Extend Spell, but I wouldn't choose Great Wisdom. You must understand how much of this build revolves around Wisdom. You gain AB with Wisdom thanks to Zen Archery, you gain AC with Wisdom thanks to Monk AC, you gain spells per day with Wisdom thanks to Cleric, higher DCs for your spells, so the last thing you want to do is drop ANY Wisdom at all. If I had to choose a feat to drop for Extend Spell, I would drop Epic Prowess. It "just" gives you +1 AB.

I lost the link to the stored database, but I do know that there are very similar builds. But since we started from scratch, I thought this one deserves a topic here.

My offensive spell selection is vital to understand how to use the build, and also why I chose to give up Extend and Empower for more Wisdom:

Lvl 1 - Divine Favor
Lvl 2 - There are no good ones, so I put Invisibility here for scouting / fleeing.
Lvl 3 - Searing Light (put many buffs here, as Searing Light is half-worthless). I use it much to finish off creatures I have used Harm on. You need do only 1d4 damage, and Divine damage resistance isn't common. It prevents you from wasting a better spell to finish off near dead enemies, which is good.
Lvl 4 - Hammer of the Gods (mostly for the stun effect on low-will saving types)
Lvl 5 - Flamestrike
Lvl 6 - Harm / Blade Barrier
Lvl 7 - Word of Faith
Lvl 8 - Fire Storm
Lvl 9 - IMPLOSION (It deserves capital letters )

As you can see, there are good offensive spells or buffs to use in abundance at each spell level. You will have a high enough WIS score to choose any number that is sufficient to last you through the day. The high caster level means you don't NEED Extend, and the availability of good offensive spells at all levels means you don't NEED empower. If I could squeeze them in without hurting my sniping or lowering my Wisdom, those two feats would be my next choice, alas you need to decide between being the best at what you do or being able to do more things. I chose the former. But as KillerKat suggested, you could go with them as well without hurting the idea. Another of his suggestions which kinda made me think for a while was dropping Martial weapons and settling for a sling. But I don't think I have EVER seen a WoG mob drop a sling or bullets consistently, so I chose to keep the bow, as there are places where you can stock up on fire arrows for free. Still, if you do decide to go with this, take Silent Spell, and you can prevent casters from casting if you cast silence on yourself and approach them. I, however, find that you are already a caster's worst nightmare, alongside high SR monks, so you needn't dwell on that much.

You know that NASTY mage boss that has killed many of your toons with IGMS, Bigby's 9 and then some other crap? Approach him / her invisible and fire one single Implosion. Revenge will be yours! Or stay from afar, sniping the shit out of them, not allowing them to cast.

Another thing I need to address here is the domain selection. I chose Plant because in regular NWN, the only item slot that buffs natural AC is the amulet, which happens to be the same that buffs Wisdom. But if your server, like WoG, has plenty of non-amulet custom items that enhance Natural AC or alternatively Wisdom belts, or cloaks, or helms, then Plant is droppable. Trickery is the main one, because I use invisibility to scout a lot, and because of the 50% concealment, which is great against archers. You needn't worry about meleers, as most of the time they will not manage to get close to you. In WoG, pick any god that has trickery and allows you to be lawful. I don't know them by hard yet, so I don't know which ones.

In the early levels, I usually summon a lot with 8 STR Clerics. I have 3 of those: this guy, my Cleric Wizard Monk and my Shadow Priest build, which I will post here soon enough. Let the summons be your meatshield and rain arrows from afar, or use all your slots in lvl 2 for invisibility and all others as Summon Creature and just watch them do the dirty work for ya. That will work in WoG.

You can take Rogue at 40 is to avoid XP penalty, but then you'll lose a couple of minor things: 1 to saves vs spells (Spellcraft 45) and 1 Concentration, besides 2 levels of full Tumble AC and UMD. Either way is fine, really.

This is a quite cheap build, I realize, so if you don't want to risk being drunk with power, my advice is not to try it .

Whaddya think? Hip, see how much it changed since that early draft I sent you?

Take it EZ!
Hi Max,

Selecting trickery u lose animal domain, but I think it's better.

I lost the link to the stored database, but I do know that there are very similar builds. But since we started from scratch, I thought this one deserves a topic here.

My offensive spell selection is vital to understand how to use the build, and also why I chose to give up Extend and Empower for more Wisdom:

Lvl 1 - Divine Favor
Lvl 2 - There are no good ones, so I put Invisibility here for scouting / fleeing.
Lvl 3 - Searing Light (put many buffs here, as Searing Light is half-worthless). I use it much to finish off creatures I have used Harm on. You need do only 1d4 damage, and Divine damage resistance isn't common. It prevents you from wasting a better spell to finish off near dead enemies, which is good.
Lvl 4 - Hammer of the Gods (mostly for the stun effect on low-will saving types)
Lvl 5 - Flamestrike
Lvl 6 - Harm / Blade Barrier
Lvl 7 - Word of Faith
Lvl 8 - Fire Storm
Lvl 9 - IMPLOSION (It deserves capital letters )

As you can see, there are good offensive spells or buffs to use in abundance at each spell level. You will have a high enough WIS score to choose any number that is sufficient to last you through the day. The high caster level means you don't NEED Extend, and the availability of good offensive spells at all levels means you don't NEED empower. If I could squeeze them in without hurting my sniping or lowering my Wisdom, those two feats would be my next choice, alas you need to decide between being the best at what you do or being able to do more things. I chose the former. But as KillerKat suggested, you could go with them as well without hurting the idea. Another of his suggestions which kinda made me think for a while was dropping Martial weapons and settling for a sling. But I don't think I have EVER seen a WoG mob drop a sling or bullets consistently, so I chose to keep the bow, as there are places where you can stock up on fire arrows for free. Still, if you do decide to go with this, take Silent Spell, and you can prevent casters from casting if you cast silence on yourself and approach them. I, however, find that you are already a caster's worst nightmare, alongside high SR monks, so you needn't dwell on that much.

You know that NASTY mage boss that has killed many of your toons with IGMS, Bigby's 9 and then some other crap? Approach him / her invisible and fire one single Implosion. Revenge will be yours! Or stay from afar, sniping the shit out of them, not allowing them to cast.

Another thing I need to address here is the domain selection. I chose Plant because in regular NWN, the only item slot that buffs natural AC is the amulet, which happens to be the same that buffs Wisdom. But if your server, like WoG, has plenty of non-amulet custom items that enhance Natural AC or alternatively Wisdom belts, or cloaks, or helms, then Plant is droppable. Trickery is the main one, because I use invisibility to scout a lot, and because of the 50% concealment, which is great against archers. You needn't worry about meleers, as most of the time they will not manage to get close to you. In WoG, pick any god that has trickery and allows you to be lawful. I don't know them by hard yet, so I don't know which ones.

In the early levels, I usually summon a lot with 8 STR Clerics. I have 3 of those: this guy, my Cleric Wizard Monk and my Shadow Priest build, which I will post here soon enough. Let the summons be your meatshield and rain arrows from afar, or use all your slots in lvl 2 for invisibility and all others as Summon Creature and just watch them do the dirty work for ya. That will work in WoG.

You can take Rogue at 40 is to avoid XP penalty, but then you'll lose a couple of minor things: 1 to saves vs spells (Spellcraft 45) and 1 Concentration, besides 2 levels of full Tumble AC and UMD. Either way is fine, really.

This is a quite cheap build, I realize, so if you don't want to risk being drunk with power, my advice is not to try it .

Whaddya think? Hip, see how much it changed since that early draft I sent you?

Take it EZ!
Hi Max,

In WoG you can't choose the domains you suggest, but which one do you think is the best to focus, plant and animal maybe, or trickery + whatever.
Selecting trickery u lose animal domain, but I think it's better.
I played this build on WoG to level 39, I think. I went with Ehlonna, Animal and Plant. This build here is the version I would choose if I could choose any domain, but the WoG restrictions make it impossible, so there domains must be changed.

The thing is that you play this build as an Archer, and nothing better than improved summons to serve as tanks for you, although they won't be good forever. You can easily get to level 30 with Animal and Plant, but then you'll need to team up with someone to tank for you, while you rain destruction from a distance.

posts.content: I like this build and plan to start the game as an archer. My idea is to combine zen archery with wisdom bonuses for a good AB and to also gain various spells. Do you think this build could work for a druid instead of a cleric? My plan is to snipe from behind, while having a druid's animal companion + henchmen + summon + dominated animal as a solid barricade to prevent enemies from approaching, you can also buff them with spells like Stoneskin and Barkskin. My plan is to run OC/SOU + HOTU campaign with that, any suggestions if druid would work that way?

It's true that Clerics can also summon, but they don't have animal companions, which are quite powerful up to pre-Epic levels, especially at low levels, also Clerics can't dominate animals. Plus Druids have better spells for defending to buff your barricade line. Additionally, if you have Bard henchmen, it will further buff a LARGE party, where the benefits become even greater.  And regarding divine favour, Druids have something better to boost Wisdom and AB because of Zen Archery - Owl's insight (probably...?). These were my first thoughts. I guess, I will try BOTH ways to figure out which one suits best.

Hey there!

The thing about Druids is that they don't have any offensive buffs to directly raise AB and damage. Clerics have Divine Power, Divine Favour, bless, Aid, Battletide, Prayer, etc.. The only thing Druid can do better than Clerics is buff Wisdom, but the cap of that buff is +6 to the modifier (+12 to the stat). Clerics can equip a Periapt of Wisdom and cast Owl's Wisdom, get around +4 to the modifier (+8 to the stat). Just Divine Power + Divine Favour gives a direct buff of +10 to AB. So, unfortunately, using Druid here you will not get the same results.

Take it EZ!
